Service Types are used to classify services into broad categories.

For example, OC–48, 10G, T1 are all service types. New service types may be added as necessary. In the service table the service type may be used as a sort key to help find the services of the same type. Service types may be identified as physical or logical. This determines how the service is treated on topology (map) screens. Only physical services are shown on maps. The service type definitions editor allows you to configure and manage service types.
BPUAA comes with 15 default Topological Service Layers. Below table shows the default Service Types associated to each layer.
MPLS-LSP, ATM-PVC, EVC, L2 VPN, L3 VPN, Pseudo wires, VLAN, EVPN-VPLS,EVPN-VLL, Pathkey
E1, E2, E3, E4, E5, T1, T2, T3, DS0, DS1, DS2, DS3, DS4, DS5
Eg VC12, VC3, VC4, VC4-c, STS-1, 3, 12, SONET, SDH path
100GbE, 40GbE, 10GbE, 10GbE LAN, 10GbE WAN, 1 GbE, layer 2 adjacency, ip layer 2
OC-3, 12, 48, 192, 768 or STM1, 4, 16, 64, 256, SONET, SDH LINE, SONET, SDH Section
ODU0, ODU1, ODUflex, ODU2, ODU1e, ODU2e, ODU3 and ODU4
OTU1, OTU1e, OTU2, OTU2e, OTU3 and OTU4

BPUAA enables you to create domains and assign the Configurable items to any of the domains. Every configurable object in BPUAA, except for the system level configurations has to be associated with a domain.
When BPUAA is upgraded to latest version, a default domain gets created and all configuration objects get assigned to that default domain. The users will not be assigned to any domain.
The Default domain contains the configuration items that are not specific to any domain.
Any user without domain assignment will be considered global user. Only a global admin user can create, edit or delete a domain.

If a user belonging to a particular domain creates any of the configurable objects such as alarm correlation policy, then the it will be assigned to the domain of the user. If a global user creates the configurable object, then the Domain drop-down list is available to specify the domain for the configurable object.

Enable Enrichment acts as a switch to enable or disable Custom Alarm Field Enrichment. After creating a custom field, it is committed with enrichment configuration and then the changes are available in the upcoming alarms. Once enrichment is enabled, the additional fields would be visible to provide enrichment configuration.

After the enrichment (either single or multiple), if the size of the resultant value is greater than the column size mentioned in the format for the particular custom alarm field, the system would trim the value to the appropriate size.

A Resource Adapter is a set of configuration information that tells BPUAA how to communicate with any given device. The currently supported protocols and thus Resource Adapter types are ASCII, SNMP, CORBA and TL1. Resource Adapters are created for each type of device that is supported. In general this information contains -

Specifically, the format and content of this information differs widely depending upon the needs of the communication protocol. Once defined and properly imported into the system, these Resource Adapters are available for the system to assign automatically during the node discovery process or for network administrators to assign while manually adding nodes to the system.

Resource Adapters are stored as a series of XML documents bundled into a zip file with a .pro file extension. These files are stored in the /bp2/data/profiles directory of the BPUAA application server main file system. The server continuously examines the contents of this directory looking for any new or changed Resource Adapters.

header: KEY CONCEPTS AND DEFINITIONS ASCII RESOURCE ADAPTER CONCEPTS

content.text: An ASCII device is any device that has a communication interface that is text based. BPUAA provides specific support for TL1 based ASCII devices as described later in this chapter but these devices could be supported with an ASCII Resource Adapter as well.
content.header: KEY CONCEPTS AND DEFINITIONS ASCII RESOURCE ADAPTER CONCEPTS

content.text: As there is no standard for ASCII devices, the Resource Adapter must be sufficiently generic so it can apply to anything. To accomplish this BPUAA uses the concepts of patterns, events, keywords, translators, and property assignments to capture, identify, and convert ASCII messages into BPUAA events.
content.header: KEY CONCEPTS AND DEFINITIONS ASCII RESOURCE ADAPTER CONCEPTS

content.text: A pattern is a pattern or format of characters that signify or identify something.

In BPUAA, patterns are used to eliminate message boundaries and to find common parts of the messages themselves. The common parts of the message are generally assigned to standard properties that can be used later in keyword matching or alarm attribute assignment. The set of standard properties is unique to each device.
An event is a collection of keywords, translators, and alarm property assignments that are used to:

There are two types of events in BPUAA: template events and standard events. A template event is an event that dynamically creates new standard events based upon the message information it captures. This is very powerful and allows BPUAA to “learn” or “discover” standard events from a device without an operator manually entering them. This is accomplished by defining dynamic raise or clear keywords in the event.
A standard event is static and unchanging and is used to identify a specific ASCII message and convert that message to a BPUAA event.

A keyword is a set of characters the system should look for in an ASCII message. The system can look for these characters either in standard properties or on a specific line of a message. There are three types of keywords -

The set of raise keywords constitutes a pattern of text that the server must find in a message for it to match a raise of a given event definition. Similarly the set of clear keywords constitutes a pattern of text that the server must find in a message for it to match a clear of any given event definition.

Info keywords are used to dynamically capture text from a message that can be assigned arbitrarily to a BPUAA event. Info keyword values typically change constantly, such as a timestamp or a sequence number and therefore cannot be used to identify the event.

All keyword types can be either static or dynamic. Static keywords contain a specific set of characters to search for, such as LOS. Dynamic keywords contain instructions for dynamically capturing text from the message based on certain parameters. For example: look on line 2, start capturing after the first “:” and capture to the end of the line.
Static events contain only static raise and clear keywords while dynamic events can have a mix of static or dynamic raise and clear keywords. Either event type can have dynamic info keywords.

A translator is a text–to–text mapping that you can use to translate ASCII text values into something more readable. For example, a device emits a number that indicates the type of alarm that occurred.

These numbers are not very user friendly and have to be interpreted by an operator. A translator can be used to map each number to a user friendly description. In this case, this could look something like translate the text “1” to “LOS”, translate the text “2” to “LOF”, and so on.
After matching a particular event definition, the set of raise and info keywords are then used to convert the message into a BPUAA event.

This is accomplished with alarm property assignments wherein you can configure which keywords values are assigned to which BPUAA event properties. Optionally, each property can be passed through translators to convert raw ASCII values if desired.

The Common Object Request Broker Architecture (CORBA) is a standard that enables software components written in multiple computer languages and running on multiple computers to work together; which means it supports multiple platforms.
Autonomous ASCII message parsing is accomplished in two stages. In the first stage the server looks for patterns of text that indicate a start of message and an end of message.

The lines of text between these messages are collected and handed to the second stage as a unit, a message. Furthermore, the start of message pattern usually contains some standard fields for that type of device.
An example of this would be all syslog messages begin with a time stamp. The first stage parse can find these standard fields and pass them to the second stage parse as “standard properties”.

In the second stage of parsing the server looks for combinations of keywords that would indicate a particular raise or clear message. These keywords are either found in a standard property or on a particular line number.
The incoming message is evaluated against the entire set of events defined for that device and the best match is chosen based upon the number of matching keywords.
These keywords then assigned to specific alarm properties using the alarm property assignments and translators.

The Resource Adapters page lists all the developed Resource Adapters for all four types: ASCII, SNMP, TL1 and CORBA. On the Resource Adapters page, you can install any of the available Resource Adapters, or update the Resource Adapters if any latest version is available for the installed Resource Adapter.

When adding a new node in BPUAA, a Resource Adapter installed must be selected. There is an option to provide an ASCII device Resource Adapter for a device. If an ASCII device Resource Adapter is not selected, a new one gets created automatically.

This ASCII device Resource Adapter will use the ASCII Resource Adapter as its Ancestor. An ASCII device Resource Adapter therefore implicitly includes all the text translators and event definitions that are part of its Ancestor ASCII Resource Adapter. These definitions can be overridden and new definitions can be added in ASCII device Resource Adapter using edit ASCII pages detailed later in this section.

Settings allows users to adjust the system settings of the respective BPUAA feature.

In general, a setting is an adjustment or value in a software program or on a hardware device that adjusts it to the user's preference. Based on their assigned roles, some users are restricted from accessing some of the pages and functionality.
In BPUAA, each feature have configurable settings as per the use. Listed below are the Settings -
The Alarm Settings editor is used to configure fault processing options. The Alarm editor contains the following segments -

The Fault Processing segment contains fields that control which events are processed by the system. By default all autonomous events from all devices are processed and stored in event history. This can prove to be too much information in some cases.

Using the Fault Processing form fields the user can make required changes. Refer to Table below for a list of Fault Processing tab settings and their descriptions. Click the Save button to enter the change or the Cancel button to stop.
Process non alarmed events (severity lower than Minor)
Select this check box if you want BPUAA to process all events even with a severity level lower than minor.
This checkbox is selected by default.
If selected, the system’s default alarm threshold policy will be assigned to all end points that have elected to “Use system’s default policy”.
If cleared, no threshold policy will be applied to these end points
Update the existing alarm count from n to n+1
Select this check box to hide the cleared alarms in the active and service alarm tables. Clear this check box to display the cleared alarms.
This checkbox is selected by default.
Select this check box to hide all the acknowledged and then cleared alarms. Clear this check box to display all the acknowledged and cleared alarms.
Cleared alarms are retained in the active alarm list for a certain period of time. This is set to 14400 seconds (4 hours) by default.

A flapping alarm is an alarm which is continuously raised and cleared over a period of time. In some cases, each raise and clear can happen too quickly for the customer to see it in the Active Alarms page. This can cause a recurring issue to be missed.
This option is not selected by default.
The default value is set to 1.
to add the flapping alarm count

The flapping alarm should be cleared manually. An alarm is considered as flapping alarm when the alarm count exceeds 'Flapping Alarm count' (x) with in clear persistence period (y second) that is, an alarm is said to be flapping if it raises x times in y seconds.
Specify the alarm scan frequency. The system will scan all the network alarms in the specified frequency and if there is any change, it will be updated in the Network Alarms page.
For every 60 seconds, the system scans the available alarm correlation policies against the active alarm lists. You can change the value of this field.
The default correlation scan frequency is 60 seconds.
Number of threads required to calculate the service impact analysis.
By default 3 threads will be running to calculate the service impact analysis. You can edit the value in the spin box if you wish to increase or decrease the number of threads.
Alarm duration can be calculated based on -

Alarm's duration will be calculated based on the alarm's 'raised time' if it is available. If 'raised time' is empty 'duration' will be calculated based on 'Received time' of alarm and when the alarm gets cleared, 'cleared time' will get set to clear trap's 'raised time' if available else , 'cleared time' will get set to received time.
This field is enabled when Enable root cause analysis check box is selected. The default scan period is set to 1 second.

The Communication Settings editor allows the user to configure low–level southbound communication settings. Some of these settings apply to and are shared by all communication protocols, while others are specific to a single protocol. A configuration setting starts with the protocol name when it is specific to a protocol.

The BPUAA server maintains pools of threads or sets of simultaneous processes for southbound communication. These pools can be sized down to limit the number of concurrent requests to reduce network traffic. They can also be sized up to increase parallelism and performance. There are trade–offs for changing the number of threads or pool sizes and the defaults represent the best compromise. Thread settings should only be changed if recommended by BPUAA technical support.

Statistical baseline data calculation is a feature that significantly improves the accuracy and validity of established performance benchmarks. Baseline is used to detect and alert on deviations from the average values. Baseline is calculated based on the normal historical distribution of data, taking the mean and standard deviations into account.
BPUAA provides performance statistics and threshold comparisons to give you a clear picture of network performance.

Baselining in BPUAA depicts the mean and standard deviation values of performance that have been observed from past N weeks for a given metric. Baseline statistics are calculated daily, and they are used to define thresholds in charts and alerts.
With baselining feature in BPUAA, you have the following advantages -
The Analytics Settings page allows us to enable Baseline feature globally.

The BPUAA AI Apps provides features and functions that allow users to predict the network problems. It provides a broad overview to your network and allows you to drill into network issues for specific details.

The BPUAA AI App Manager provides features and functions that allow users to predict the network problems. It provides a broad overview to your network and allows you to drill into network issues for specific details.
The AI App Manager is now part of the BP App Bar UI. Select the AI App Manager from the BP App Bar UI for running the use cases.
Any user can start and stop an App. However, Apps can be managed only by the Blue Planet team.

These Apps allows user to manage network issue identifiers and resolutions. AI Apps are a combination of alarm and facility types that user wants to monitor or predict. For every network issue, apps provides probable root causes and predictions. Once the apps are created and executed, Network Health Analytics app displays predicted network issues to operators whenever the network conditions match those in the app.
The AI Apps window lists all created apps. Selecting an app displays the following sections:

Different types of AI Apps exist under the list. All the apps are created by Blue Planet using the templates. A template is a pre-loaded sequence of events that can be used to perform a prediction. Though the data present in the template may not be the current data, the user with Blue Planet’s support can use a template with the current and required data to perform a particular prediction.
AI Apps provides the following 7 production app templates -

The Alarm Prioritization app categorize the alarms depending on the network issues using ML model driven approach. These apps classify inflowing network alarms into important/noise(non-important) with corresponding probability (of being important) which helps the NOC to take quick action. The ML model is trained with a Binary classifier Supervised ML technique using the history of network fault alarms with necessary alarm attributes (such as severity, device type, and specific problem) and labels (presence of any comment/NOC ticket/service id) as input. The trained model is used to predict the live network alarms (important/noise) and suppress the noisy alarms using filter.
For the first time, user need to run the app in the following order:

Once the Inference is started, there is no need to manually restart the Inference; the scheduled ML Training app will restart it whenever model promotion occurs. As a result, there is no need to schedule Inference App because it is a streaming app that can be invoked whenever needed by the ML Training app.
There are 3 different types of UAA Alarm Prioritization Apps -
Comma separated list of ML algorithm classifiers for automl. Supported classifier are -

To enhance the PM Monitoring capabilities, UAA now has the ability of Bulk Enable option. This feature empowers users to efficiently configure PM Monitoring Policies and perform monitoring tasks in bulk.
This AI (Artificial Intelligent) app aims to forecast the PM Anomaly by taking into account a user-defined threshold crossing and automatically triggering an alarm.
In addition to the ability to automatically raise alarms, this feature can automatically clear alarms if they go unattended for a predetermined amount of time.
Once we're here, we can see two apps under BPA PM Monitoring AI:
The Data-Quality app ensures that we have enough data before running the Inference App.
Number of time steps to Look Back

This setting is crucial for validating the accuracy of the Forecast feature. By default, it is set to 3. This means that the Forecasted Threshold Crossing is considered a true positive if the Forecasted Date falls within plus or minus 3 time-steps of the Present Threshold Crossing date if both are from the same policy.
Clear the active Smart Alarms, if the corresponding AI PM policy is deleted/de-activated
This option ensures that if a PM policy associated with the AI is deleted or deactivated, all active smart alarms related to that policy will be cleared.

This feature clears all active smart alarms when the dead-banding criteria are met. The term "dead-banding" refers to the range of values within which no action is taken if the PM value falls. The alarm is triggered when the PM values exceed the threshold set by the user, and it is automatically cleared when the values cross the dead-band zone and move into the normal range zone, away from the set thresholds.

content.text: The cross-layer stitching function is to discover direct physical connections between optical interfaces and IP router interfaces, which cannot be obtained by traditional protocols, based on machine learning based methods.

The performance metrics of both optical and IP router interfaces are the basic and also the inputs of the cross-layer stitching module. This can be achieved by deploying UAA, if the customer does have an existing performance monitoring system, the cross-layer stitching module can also work with it, but additional customizations are needed.

The fiber degradation app identifies problematic optical line fibers by measuring the degradation in the span loss. Fibers for which the span loss has increased by more than 0.5dB relative to a historical baseline are flagged as problematic. Although fibers that support both long and short-range connections exist in most networks, in this release, only long-range line fibers that connect amplifiers are considered.
For the fiber app, the baseline estimation of span loss is computed from historical data as the span loss during the earliest known period of stable span loss.
There are two different types of UAA Fiber degradation Apps:
There are no parameters to configure here. Users can directly run the use case.

This feature allows to track and see all the impacted service associated to an alarm in UAA. So whenever an alarm is raised on any node or service, then user can see list of services that could be impacted by the incident, further this details can be used as an insight that how much impact this incident is making in network system by looking at all impacted services and then proper action can be taken dependent on urgency of the issue.
There are 3 components to the app -
There are no parameters to configure here. Users can directly run the use case.

The Silent Fault Detection AI App uses symptomatic alarms at service endpoints combined with network topology to identify the mostly likely root cause of the issues. This is especially useful for Passive Optical Networks (PONs) where the root cause equipment does not report alarms, or for noisy networks where the root cause alarm is drowned out by other alarms on the network, making manual root cause analysis difficult.
There are 2 components to the app -
BPI server ID. This is a required field.

BPI must be installed on a separate server/cluster. The postgres port must be open in order for the Silent Fault Detection app to read the topology from BPI.
Credentials to read the BPI postgres database must be entered as a parameter to the Al App when starting it.

The Alarm Noise Reduction use cases categorize the alarms depending on the network issues using ML model driven approach. These use cases classify inflowing network alarms into important/noise(non-important) with corresponding probability (of being important) which helps the NOC to take quick action.

The Alarm Prioritization use case categorizes the incoming network/device alarms depending upon the network issues using the ML driven approach. The use case is capable of classifying the inflowing network alarms into Important(Actionable) vs noise(non-Actionable) and predicting the priority of Alarm into one of the four priority categories 'Low/Normal/High/Urgent' which helps the NOC engineers to prioritize the alarms and helps to take quick action against the really vital network alarms.
Network alarm should flow continually in the UAA system in-order to allow the Alarm Prioritization AI/ML analytics use case monitor those alarms and make required forecasts.

For each execution, the cross-layer stitching module will query performance metrics from UAA's database, carry pre-defined data pre-processing, and feed into machine learning model. The full inference results will be recorded in UAA's database, and show in the UI. For easy view, only the connected pairs, a.k.a. the cross-layer links, will be shown in the UI in default.

User can change the filtering condition to show all the results. User can also provide feedback on inference results through the UI. Meanwhile, the inference result will also be sent out to specific kafka topic for being pickup by other software like BPI.

content.text: PM Anomaly Forecast (PM Monitoring) is an innovative solution designed specifically for real-time monitoring of network endpoints and performance metrics, as well as forecasting future timeline events.
PM Monitoring is BPA's innovative and a cutting-edge solution which is designed to monitor the network endpoints and performance metrics.

In today's rapidly evolving era, the ability to dynamically scale network resources to meet future traffic demands is very crucial. The AI App addresses this critical need through advanced forecasting techniques, considering seasonality trends, and automated anomaly detection.
This feature empowers users to efficiently configure PM Monitoring Policies and perform monitoring tasks in bulk.
By activating this feature, AI App can easily identify the Present threshold-crossing events based on user-defined thresholds.
By activating this feature, AI App can easily identify the Future threshold-crossing events based on user-defined thresholds.
If user-defined thresholds are not provided, then with the help of AI App, user can detect Statistical Anomaly as well.
If this feature is enabled, AI App can autonomously identify the statistical anomalies without manual threshold setting.
PM Monitoring AI App has an innovative dashboard that provides enough insights to help user to take timely actions.

The Silent Fault Detection AI App uses symptomatic alarms at service endpoints combined with network topology to identify the mostly likely root cause of the issues. This is especially useful for Passive Optical Networks (PONs) where the root cause equipment does not report alarms, or for noisy networks where the root cause alarm is drowned out by other alarms on the network, making manual root cause analysis difficult.

The Silent Fault Detection (SFD) dashboard is provided in the UAA menu bar. A summary of the recent root causes identified (raised as smart alarms) and their corresponding symptomatic alarms are available in this dashboard.

The Silent Fault Detection AI App uses symptomatic alarms at service endpoints combined with network topology to identify the mostly likely root cause of the issues. This is especially useful for Passive Optical Networks (PONs) where the root cause equipment does not report alarms, or for noisy networks where the root cause alarm is drowned out by other alarms on the network, making manual root cause analysis difficult.

In addition to the ability to automatically raise alarms, this feature can automatically clear alarms if they go unattended for a predetermined amount of time. It also has the ability to ignore any symptomatic devices for which their parent devices exhibit any of a pre-defined set of alarms.

The user has the ability to schedule the app. Once a schedule is established, this batch app will run on a regular basis in accordance with the user's schedule and find faults for the present and future tense periods.

Common user actions are grouped into distinct user roles.
User accounts can be assigned one or more user roles depending upon the amount of authorization required. Default roles divided in two sections -
The set of user interfaces presented to each user is customized by the set of access roles and any access control lists that are associated with the user.
User roles are additive for the most part, but some combinations do not make sense and are not allowed. Users assigned the Customer and Read–Only roles cannot be assigned any other roles.
